sectionTitle: Real-World Factors Favoring a High Dividend Payout

columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine the reason why some individual investors favor a high dividend payout and some non-individual investors prefer a high dividend pay-out.

## Requirement 17.4a

Some individual investors favor a high dividend payout because they want to generate money through dividends and avoid the costs of buying and selling stocks. Another reason is that investors can buy a larger dividend and sell it at a higher price.

## Requirement 17.4b

Some non-individual investors prefer a high dividend pay-out because it provides a tax benefit for owning stock in another company and decreases capital gains tax. Additionally, some of their investors are restricted the principal spending. Another reason is non-individual investors to have a high yield dividend for more available cash.
This exercise will determine the tax and other benefits derived from the high dividend payout.

### KEY TERMS

* **Capital gains tax** - this are the tax imposed on the investors who sold their property or investments.

* **Dividends** - refers to the resources earned by the entity that is paid out to its shareholders. This may be in the form of cash, property, or stocks.

### Requirement A

The **individual investors** or those that are not form part of the corporation or large investors, or those who received a fixed amount of income regularly, would rather choose to pay for a higher premium to invest on the high-dividends.

Individual investors look after on the savings they will be made since high dividends would not involve brokerage fees and transaction costs unlike the low dividends.

### Requirement B

**Nonindividual investors** are the corporations who hold shares of stocks to another entity and those investors who are tax-exempt.

Corporations and tax-exempt investors prefer a high dividend payout since on the former, they are granted an essential **tax break**. Because of low capital gains tax to be derived from the high-dividend due to exclusion, corporations find it favorable to hold these kind of securities as compared to the bonds that have no tax benefit to be derived from paying interest.

The **tax-exempt investors** or those investors that hold a significant amount of securities that help the economy, such as trust funds. They are given the benefit to be included on the **zero-tax bracket**.

This is mainly because their large investments are significant enough to help move the economy of the country.

To conclude, **individual investors** and **nonindividual investors** both prefer a high dividend payout. They only differ on the reasons why they prefer such dividends.

On the former, they prefer high-dividend payout to save some money on brokerage fees and transaction costs associated to the securities. On the other hand, the latter choose high-dividend payout to make use of the tax benefits granted to them.
